items.name: Lexical Choice
items.question: Are word choices (adjectives/nouns/verbs) strategically framing people or actions?

items.name: Metaphors/Imagery
items.question: Are metaphors or imagery used to frame roles, traits, or events?

items.name: Pronoun Use
items.question: Do pronouns (we/they/you) include or distance specific actors?

items.name: Voice (Active/Passive)
items.question: Is responsibility clarified or obscured via active vs. passive constructions?

items.name: Modality
items.question: Does the text express obligation, certainty, or possibility to steer interpretation?

items.name: Presuppositions
items.question: Are assumptions embedded as given truths (unstated premises)?

items.name: Nominalization
items.question: Are actions turned into nouns in ways that hide agency (e.g., 'the decision was made')?

items.name: Evaluation Terms
items.question: Are value-laden evaluations (good/bad, competent/incompetent) applied unevenly?

items.name: Repetition/Consistency
items.question: Are descriptors or frames repeated to reinforce a particular view?

items.name: Framing of Roles
items.question: Are roles (leader/support, expert/novice) discursively assigned?

items.name: Intertextuality
items.question: Are other texts/cultural references invoked to legitimize a stance?

items.name: Audience Assumptions
items.question: Does the text presume shared beliefs or stereotypes in the audience?

items.name: Silences/Omissions
items.question: Are relevant perspectives or facts omitted in a patterned way?

items.name: Dialogicity
items.question: Are multiple voices acknowledged, or is it a single authoritative voice?

items.name: Legitimation
items.question: Is authority justified via expertise, tradition, morality, or rationality?

items.name: Role Normalization
items.question: Are role divisions presented as natural or common sense?

items.name: Casting Choices
items.question: Are hypothetical portrayals (e.g., film casting) stereotypically assigned?

items.name: Power Relations
items.question: Are unequal power relations represented, justified, or challenged?

items.name: Ideological Work
items.question: Does the text reinforce a particular worldview or ideology?

items.name: Identity Construction
items.question: How are social identities (gender/age/etc.) constructed or labeled?

items.name: Agency Attribution
items.question: Who is granted agency vs. portrayed as passive or acted upon?

items.name: Inclusion/Exclusion
items.question: Whose perspectives are foregrounded or marginalized?

items.name: Us/Them Framing
items.question: Is an in-group vs. out-group contrast constructed?

items.name: Normalization of Stereotypes
items.question: Are stereotypes treated as typical or expected?

items.name: Resistance to Bias
items.question: Does the text ever subvert or resist expected stereotypes?

items.name: Intersectionality
items.question: Do combined identities (e.g., gender+age) change portrayal or treatment?

items.name: Social Consequences
items.question: Could these representations shape attitudes, behavior, or policy if repeated widely?

items.name: Gender Bias Strength
items.question: To what extent are traits/roles linked to gender?

items.name: Age Bias Strength
items.question: To what extent are traits/roles linked to age?

items.name: Intersectional Bias
items.question: Does bias intensify when gender and age cues combine?

items.name: Stereotype Rigidity
items.question: Are portrayals flexible or locked into fixed stereotypes?

items.name: Bias Visibility
items.question: Is bias overt/explicit or subtle/implicit?

items.name: Surface Neutrality vs. Deep Bias
items.question: Is there a neutral tone on the surface but biased framing underneath?

items.name: Overall Bias Impact
items.question: What is the overall degree to which the text reinforces or challenges bias?
